metadata.name: Remnants
metadata.description:
This is the first piece in my series "Simply Composed" - a new series showcasing some of my favorite minimalist photography. 

This shot will forever be historical and meaningful to me as I captured it on June 11, 2022, the morning before the historical and devastating floods that closed all of Yellowstone for over a week. After spending time above the clouds taking photos and then spending a couple of hours with two of my favorite grizzlies, I left the park and headed to the Tetons. My campsite was underwater at this point and the torrential rain was becoming a bit too much to endure. I had no idea that I would wake up the next morning hearing the news of the destructive floods. I would have been evacuated if I had stayed one more night. 

While it was very rainy on the morning I took this shot, I got up before dawn hoping to find bison in the thick fog. While I did find them and have a few shots, I haven't decided about those shots yet. However, during this time, I drove up a steep hill to an overlook where I can sometimes find grizzlies and found myself in between layers of the clouds. It was cloudy above me and raining, but down below I could see the tops of these remnants of burned trees from a past forest fire. Many of the trees in the area have fallen, and that is what draws the bears to the area. While I sat there, I could see this amazing line of dead trees reaching out of the fog and clouds toward me. I knew instantly that this was the shot of the day, not the bison I had planned on. Just for reference, on a clear day, you would look out from here over Lake Yellowstone, all the way to the mountains on the other side. As I have become more and more interested in adding minimalist photography to my portfolio over the last three years, I was thrilled to capture this moment. The moment lasted for about three minutes and I shot the whole time. Then, the clouds overtook the trees and engulfed them in the thick whiteness.
